title: Bump django from 2.1.11 to 2.2.10

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

body:
Bumps [django](https://github.com/django/django) from 2.1.11 to 2.2.10.
Commits - [`b2c33a5`](https://github.com/django/django/commit/b2c33a57b3b98f1e90bbc2a2be2c5a6d814eed29) [2.2.x] Bumped version for 2.2.10 release. - [`c67a368`](https://github.com/django/django/commit/c67a368c16e4680b324b4f385398d638db4d8147) [2.2.x] Fixed CVE-2020-7471 -- Properly escaped StringAgg(delimiter) parameter. - [`96d6443`](https://github.com/django/django/commit/96d644312106337d714790cbedfcb227f0faa609) [2.2.x] Fixed timezones tests for PyYAML 5.3+. - [`813b33e`](https://github.com/django/django/commit/813b33eec4d3fef8c5c3d4bfbc6ac90a248680c6) [2.2.x] Added CVE-2019-19844 to the security archive. - [`e728612`](https://github.com/django/django/commit/e7286122b42d863bc1e97a846330cc63303f1c21) [2.2.x] Post-release version bump. - [`c494d90`](https://github.com/django/django/commit/c494d90c195a739a7298b073eaa6ed987c2fd0bc) [2.2.x] Bumped version for 2.2.9 release. - [`4d334be`](https://github.com/django/django/commit/4d334bea06cac63dc1272abcec545b85136cca0e) [2.2.x] Fixed CVE-2019-19844 -- Used verified user email for password reset r... - [`86befcc`](https://github.com/django/django/commit/86befcc172c23170a720b3e0c06db51a99b3da59) [2.2.x] Refs [#31073](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/django/django/issues/31073) -- Added release notes for 02eff7ef60466da108b1a33f1e4dc0... - [`f33be1e`](https://github.com/django/django/commit/f33be1e8ae2efbca5f209e2365fa35c2aaee340c) [2.2.x] Fixed [#31073](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/django/django/issues/31073) -- Prevented CheckboxInput.get_context() from mutating a... - [`e8b0903`](https://github.com/django/django/commit/e8b0903976077b951795938b260211214ed7fe41) [2.2.x] Fixed [#31006](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/django/django/issues/31006) -- Doc'd backslash escaping in date/time template filters. - Additional commits viewable in [compare view](https://github.com/django/django/compare/2.1.11...2.2.10)

[![Dependabot compatibility score](https://dependabot-badges.githubapp.com/badges/compatibility_score?dependency-name=django&package-manager=pip&previous-version=2.1.11&new-version=2.2.10)](https://help.github.com/articles/configuring-automated-security-fixes) Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting `@dependabot rebase`. [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-start) [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-end) ---
Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot use these labels` will set the current labels as the default for future PRs for this repo and language - `@dependabot use these reviewers` will set the current reviewers as the default for future PRs for this repo and language - `@dependabot use these assignees` will set the current assignees as the default for future PRs for this repo and language - `@dependabot use this milestone` will set the current milestone as the default for future PRs for this repo and language You can disable automated security fix PRs for this repo from the [Security Alerts page](https://github.com/sdevalapurkar/schedulearn/network/alerts).

title: Change Our Availabilities System to Use FullCalendar and Work on Dates instead of Days of The Week
body: Addresses #168. Only initial integration of FullCalendar has been done right now. I expect this to be a big PR which is why I thought might as well put this up for review now instead of sending a huge PR all at once. Also gives me an opportunity to hear from you guys if you have input on the design.. Here's how it looks like right now: Next steps: Make the add availabilty button work to pull up a modal so people can add availabilites to dates EDIT: for reviewers: ignore the files in this path: schedule_lessons/static/fullcalendar/ it is just the files for fullcalendar.

title: Change Setting Availabilities From Static Days of The Week to Dynamic Weeks of a Month

labels.name: V1.1
labels.description: All issues related to our v1.1 update

body:
The title is pretty cryptic so I'll expand here. So right now, a user can set their availabilities for the days of the week. Meaning I can say that I'm available on Monday's at 7pm to 9pm, but I don't really like this system because if one week, I am busy from 8pm to 9pm, I would need to go the availability page and change the timing manually. It's pretty tedious, imo. This system also has another issue. Eventually, we want to make it so that if a lesson is scheduled with me from 8pm to 9pm, my availabilities automatically update themselves and show that I am now only available from 7pm to 8pm. But let's say that a lesson is scheduled on Monday from 8pm to 9pm 2 weeks in the future. How would we update the availabilities in that scenario? We can't unless we display a user's availabilities for the future too. I think it would also be tedious for a user to enter in their availabilities for every week. So this is how I envision the availability system to look like after addressing this issue: As a tutor, when I sign up, the website will ask me when I am available during the days of the week. After that, it will autofill those timings for the availability calendar for all the weeks. After that, if someone schedules a lesson with me, the availabilities can be updated for the appropriate day. First step in accomplishing this is finding a good calendar for websites. From a simple google search, fullcalendar.io looks good, more investigation will need to be done, however.
The next step would probably be to change the way we deal with availabilities in the backend. The way I envision it is we store the work hours for a user for the days of the week but in addition to that, we also store "special availabilities", these are the availabilities that differ from the work hours that are specified. So the calendar would show normal work hours, but for those special dates, it would show the availabilities that the user saved in the database.

title: Update tutorial to work with the new layout of the website and figure out how to make it work on mobile

labels.name: mobile-related
labels.description: Issues related to the mobile webpage of Schedulearn

body: I've currently disabled the tutorial for V1.0 because we had added the settings page and it looked expectedly bad on mobile. I want to turn it on for later so some changes are necessary which are: make the tutorial work on mobile and fix it so it works on the new layout of the website. The reason I'm not setting this for the V1.1 milestone is because I expect we'll need to make some changes very soon to the way the mobile version looks and after we do that we'll need to revisit this issue again so instead of doing that, we'll just take care of this issue later.

title: Do we need a app subdirectory inside the static folder of an app module?
body:
Investigate whether it's necessary to have the project layout as such:

schedule_lessons/module_name/static/module_name/....

or if we can change it to a flatter project structure such as:

schedule_lessons/module_name/static/...

title: Inside all the submodules for schedule-lessons, move the images and fonts to the static root folder
Template tags
body: Are we still using template tags directory and the python code within that directory @AhmedNSidd ??

title: Use error callback for ajax requests in the codebase.
body: Right now, there are instances in the js codebase where errors are being handled in the success callback. We need to fix this so the error callback handles the errors. Right now what we're (probably) doing is just returning a jsonresponse(json). What we should be doing is assigning jsonresponse(json) to a variable and then changing the status_code of that variable to the error status code that you want and then that will make sure the error callback is being called. Simply returning the jsonresponse the way we were doing it always returns a 200 status code and ajax thinks everything went well so it calls the success callback.

title: Add frontend form validation wherever possible
body:
A good point was brought up by @sdevalapurkar in #133 that we're doing backend error checking for simple form validation like empty forms. We should try avoiding this and add more frontend error checking too. This is probably going to be a long issue to resolve. This issue may be related to a potential issue in the future which is that we're not using Django Forms, and maybe we should be. [Read more about it here](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/2.2/ref/forms/api/). If anyone has good resources on best ways to do error checking in general when it comes to a web app then that'd be appreciated. 

Considering this is a high-effort, low-reward deal on the user's side I would say this is a low priority but eventually something that would be good to look into to fix if someone has time.

title: Add a "Recently Cancelled Lessons" section
body: Title says it all

title: Add a tab to display lesson details in Agenda.
Edge case: When a schedulee changes his availability timings, lessons already booked outside of his new timings should be tagged as such.
body: Here's the situation: If a person schedules a lesson (let's say it's a student) and the tutor accepts the lesson, then let's say the tutor changes his availability timings. Any booked and pending lessons that are outside of the new availability timings should be tagged as such. There should be a warning sign next to the lesson or something to show that the lesson is outside of the availability timing

title: If two lessons in the agenda page have conflicting timings, then give an alert warning badge
body: In the agenda page, if two lessons have conflicting timings, then give an alert badge (similar to the image except red) saying something like "Lesson1 and lesson2 have conflicting timings, you can only schedule one of them"

title: For tutors, give them an option in the profile menu to disallow students to book lessons with them
body:
In the edit profile page, we should give tutors a setting option where they can block lesson requests from students. This will make it so only tutors can have the ability to schedule or reschedule lessons

Side note: we should make distinct preferences and edit profile pages

title: Give the tutor a feature to add a note to all people who are trying to schedule a lesson with him.
body:
When a lesson is being scheduled, there is a person who's doing the scheduling and another person who's going to receive the details of a lesson request. The former will be referred to as the scheduler, the latter as the receiver.

It'd be pretty nice if we added a profile field for a user called something like: "scheduler_message". The purposes of this would be is if a receiver wanted to let a scheduler know of a specific change in their schedule to alert schedulers about, this could be useful. e.g. if I'm a tutor and every week I am free on Friday from 7pm - 9pm but a week comes along where there's a rare exception to the rule, then I can set up the "scheduler_message" to say something like "All my wives are giving birth on friday at 8pm so don't schedule a lesson with me at that time". 

This is a pretty involved issue so I would recommend breaking it down like this:

1. Go to schedule_lessons/accounts/models.py, to the Profile class and add a CharField with probably the same params as the bio. (After doing this make sure to run python manage.py makemigrations and then python manage.py migrate). 

These were the first backend changes. Now frontend

2. Go to schedule_lessons/templates/dashboard/edit_profile.html and add a field for the scheduler message. 

3. Then go to schedule_lessons/dashboard/static/dashboard/css/edit_profile.css to make the accompanying styling changes.

4. Everything is almost set in place. But when somebody goes to their edit profile to change their scheduler message and then presses submit, there's nothing in the backend handling what you're sending through. So now go to schedule_lessons/dashboard/views.py, find the edit_profile function. Inside this function, when the request.method == POST, get the scheduler message and save it to the user. This is an easy one line code addition: 

request.user.profile.scheduler_message = request.POST.get("scheduler_message")
